item.title: Escape from Duckov has sold 2 million copies in two weeks
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

October 28, 2025

1 Min Read

Newsbrief: Escape From Duckov has sold more than 2 million copies in two weeks. Developer Team Soda and publisher Bilibili shared the news on Steam and thanked players for their support. 

The top-down PvE indie survival RPG, which asks players to scavenge for resources to build a safe haven for their waddling yellow avatar, launched on October 16, 2025, on Steam, Epic Game Store, and MacOS. 

The title launched with an introductory 12 percent discount on Steam that ends on October 30. It has amassed almost 3,200 overwhelmingly positive user reviews on the platform at the time of writing.

item.title: Report: Amazon cutting corporate roles across key departments including video games
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

October 27, 2025

1 Min Read

Amazon intends to cut thousands of corporate roles across key departments such as logistics, payments, cloud computing, and games. 

That's according to reports from both Bloomberg and Reuters, which claim the layoffs could be announced this week and impact up to 30,000 people. 

Sources familiar with the situation told Reuters that Amazon will jettison swathes of workers to compensate for overhiring during the COVID-19 pandemic. The total number of redundancies will impact around 10 percent of the company's 350,000 person corporate workforce. Amazon currently has around 1.55 million employees globally. 

Amazon CEO Andy Jassy, who was appointed in November 2021 and has worked at the company for decades, previously told staff that generative AI tools and agents will be used to replace human workers in the coming years.

In a memo to employees published in June 2025 (thanks again, Reuters), Jassy said the technology will change how Amazon works—resulting in the need for "fewer people doing some of the jobs that are being done today, and more people doing other types of jobs." 

"It’s hard to know exactly where this nets out over time, but in the next few years, we expect that this will reduce our total corporate workforce as we get efficiency gains from using AI extensively across the company," he added in the memo.

Related:After year of layoffs, Xbox boss muses on power of devs who can sustain their own fanbase

Amazon declined to comment when approached by Bloomberg and Reuters.

item.title: Marvel Zombies was built to give Marvel Rivals players a breather
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

October 28, 2025

4 Min Read

Marvel Rivals first ever PvE mode, Marvel Zombies, arrived in timely fashion. 

The new addition to the live-service shooter debuted on October 23 (slap bang in the middle of spooky season) almost a year after the title surpassed 40 million players within 72 hours of launch in December 2024. It will be whisked away on November 14, meaning you still have a couple of weeks to take it for a spin.

During a recent chat at Gamescom Asia x Thailand Game Show, Marvel Games executive producer Danny Koo told Game Developer that Marvel Rivals' playerbase remains "healthy," which begs the question: why spend time and resources developing a new limited-time PvE game mode (aside from the obvious overlap with the recent Marvel Zombies animated series) when the core PvP experience remains in fine fettle? 

According to Koo, the intention with Marvel Zombies—and PvE in general—is to offer players a respite from the intensity of competitive play. "With Rivals being primarily a PvP game, we wanted a supplementing mode to relieve the pressure of having competition every single minute," says Koo. 

He explains the development team wanted to build a PvE mode from the outset, but were happy to wait for the right opportunity. That chance arrived following a chat with the Marvel Animation team, who explained they'd been tasked with developing a Marvel Zombies series. After watching the show, Koo realized the premise of a world overrun with crimson eyed cannon fodder was the perfect fit for a PvE experience. 

Related:Crusader Kings 3 team says addressing feedback backlogs is like 'playing darts'

Koo explains Netease Games views Marvel Zombies as a mini-game that's designed to pack a solid punch without overshadowing the core PvP experience. It took around six months of work to wrangle the mode into reality. Initially, a small strike force was assembled to cobble together a graybox prototype that would help the team understand how many players it could support and the inner workings of PvE level design.

For instance, the core PvP mode supports six players per team, but it was vital to understand whether that would translate to a PvE offering that includes kinetic hordes of enemies. Koo explains the next step was to figure out how AI foes would behave—and, as a result, which hero characters would be a good fit for PvE. The end result is a cooperative mode that supports up to four players and five heroes in Thor, Blade, Magic, Jeff the Land Shark, and The Punisher. 

"Every single player is valuable because of geography, play patterns, and how they team up with others"

A couple of those characters were included to overlap with the show. Others were intentional wild cards. "Some characters were chosen because it makes thematic sense, especially characters from the show because they have great new costumes that we can show. Others were just fan favorites like Jeff the Land Shark. He has no business being there but it's just funny to see what happens if you pit a shark against zombies," says Koo. "Then you've got The Punisher, who is like your regular military guy defending against zombies." 

Related:Survey shows young players feel pressured to conform to gender and racial stereotypes

Those characters were remixed with augmented skills and a new upgrade system to ensure they could effectively handle the huge crowds of undead that will be swarming players in Marvel Zombies. Koo says figuring out how those undead masses should attack players was also important in dictating the ebb and flow of the experience. In the end, the team landed on fast-moving mobs that can bamboozle players and incorporated hard-hitting bosses such as Namor and Scarlet Witch to bolster the challenge.

Koo believes players will learn a lot about themselves and their peers based on how they behave when the walls start closing in—but notes the difficulty curve has been fine tuned to ensure Marvel Zombies remains an enjoyable sojourn as opposed to a stifling timesink.

Related:The secrets of Dead Cells' smart constraints - Unlocking the Vault #3

"You can play Marvel Zombies solo or even as a team, so I think this mode will show players who you really are outside of competition. Whether you're cooperative, whether you care about your other teammates, or whether you want to lone wolf it," he says. 

The development team is also keen to observe player behavior, and Koo underlines the importance of ensuring all players—whether they're big spenders or those who put the 'free' in free-to-play—feel there is value in sticking around for the long haul. Ultimately, the belief is that Marvel Zombies will offer them another reason to sink their teeth into a title that Koo hopes will still be going strong in a decade. 

"When you see a player who comes in—even if they don't pay—to enjoy themselves they provide competition for other players. Every single player is valuable because of geography, play patterns, and how they team up with others. It allows us to see where their interests are and how we can create content that caters to them," says Koo. "And because this is not a pay-to-win title all of our heroes are free, we're able to see that pure engagement. Even if nobody pays, it's pure engagement."
